publicwhip.spmotion: *S1M-423# Dr Richard Simpson: Non-Housing Building Consents—That the Parliament notes the problems that smaller local authorities have with the size of non-housing building consents in respect of significant capital projects and in particular the problems faced by Clackmannanshire Council, the smallest mainland authority, where the consequences for completing vital infrastructure projects such as the A907 are problematic, and calls upon the Executive to investigate a flexible approach which recognises the problems of scale.

S1M-423# Dr Richard Simpson: Non-Housing Building Consents—That the Parliament notes the problems that smaller local authorities have with the size of non-housing building consents in respect of significant capital projects and in particular the problems faced by Clackmannanshire Council, the smallest mainland authority, where the consequences for completing vital infrastructure projects such as the A907 are problematic, and calls upon the Executive to investigate a flexible approach which recognises the problems of scale.

S1M-423# Dr Richard Simpson: Non-Housing Building Consents—That the Parliament notes the problems that smaller local authorities have with the size of non-housing building consents in respect of significant capital projects and in particular the problems faced by Clackmannanshire Council, the smallest mainland authority, where the consequences for completing vital infrastructure projects such as the A907 are problematic, and calls upon the Executive to investigate a flexible approach which recognises the problems of scale.
S1M-423# Non-Housing Building Consents (lodged on 13 January 2000) Rhoda Grant*

S1M-423# Dr Richard Simpson: Non-Housing Building Consents-That the Parliament notes the problems that smaller local authorities have with the size of non-housing building consents in respect of significant capital projects and in particular the problems faced by Clackmannanshire Council, the smallest mainland authority, where the consequences for completing vital infrastructure projects such as the A907 are problematic, and calls upon the Executive to investigate a flexible approach which recognises the problems of scale. Supported by: Dr Sylvia Jackson, Cathy Peattie, Scott Barrie, Des McNulty, Helen Eadie, Donald Gorrie, Nick Johnston, Rhoda Grant
S1M-423# Non-Housing Building Consents (lodged on 13 January 2000) Mr Kenneth Gibson*
